## 5.9

### (a)

Since the density must integrate to 1: $1 = \int_0^1 \int_0^{y_2} k(1-y_2) \, dy_1 \, dy_2 = k/6,$ so $k = 6$

### (b)

Because $Y_1 \le Y_2$, we split into two regions (drawing a picture is useful):

$$
P(Y_1 \le \tfrac{3}{4},\, Y_2 \ge \tfrac{1}{2})
= \int_{1/2}^1 \int_{1/2}^{1}6(1 - y_2)dy_1dy_2 +  \int_{1/2}^{3/4} \int_{y_1}^{1}6(1 - y_2)dy_2dy_1= \frac{24}{64} + \frac{7}{64}
= \frac{31}{64}.
$$


## 5.11

The area of the triangular region is 1, so with a uniform distribution this is the value of the density function. Again, using geometry (drawing a picture is again useful):

### (a)

$$
P(Y_1 \le \tfrac{3}{4}, Y_2 \le \tfrac{3}{4})
= 1 - P(Y_1 > \tfrac{3}{4}) - P(Y_2 > \tfrac{3}{4})
= 1 - \left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\left(\frac{1}{4}\right) - \left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)
= \frac{29}{32}.
$$

### (b)

$$
P(Y_1 - Y_2 \ge 0) = P(Y_1 \ge Y_2)
$$
The region specified in this probability statement represents 1/4 of the total region of support, so  $P(Y_1 \ge Y_2)= \frac{1}{4}$.
